content: this is dmg and we're making stalagmites when I was a kid I couldn't tell the
difference between a stalagmite and stalactite so I thought how do I
remember Estella might get to the roof and instead like direct it select what
tight has to hold on tight otherwise a fool down so what we're going to be
using is some baking paper grease paper that you'd use to cook things in the
oven with and some bits of tinfoil they've probably got left over from
making all the caves and I'm just going to roll them up into a long piece and
make one end wide and then flatten it down so it's basically just roll the the
tinfoil into a spike and push the one end so that it becomes flat and these
will form the basis of the standard mites so I'm just doing three a big one
medium one and a small one and we'll arrange them just three together and
this will be a removable piece so you could put this on the tiles permanently
but I prefer to have it as a removable piece so you can actually alter the
alter the look of the caves as you put them together so no two caves will
always be 100% identical so that's the sort of arrangement we're gonna have so
I'll just grab some hot glue straight onto the greased paper now the hot glue
will not actually stick properly to the greased paper and that's why I'm using
it it'd be easy to take it off afterwards and I'm pretty sure it's
Brian Gregory who put me onto this technique so thank you to him for that
and I'm just pushing the tin foil into the hot glue the base just a pool and
then I'm just gonna start at the top and just let the hot glue dribble down the
sides of the tin foil Peaks and if I had a smaller glue guns would probably be a
little bit easier to do but I only have the one glue gun
so if you have a smaller glue gun probably better to use that and here I'm
just extenuating the extenuating so here I'm just layering the glue down the
sides and extending the glue out in a sort of spikes from where it's flowing
down the side outwards so doesn't matter if you get along wisps here we'll deal
with that later on and that's why we're using grease paper so I'm just adding
more and more glue just to create a nice sort of natural looking base and just
keep going keep adding till you're happy with it so then I'll wait for it to dry
so here it's dry now it's it's sucking onto the paper but it's pretty simple to
just peel it off and it'll come off in one big piece with all the little
strands and wisps still attached so what we do then is we grab a pair of scissors
and just cut off the excess bits and all the wisps and things that we don't want
and tidy it up and there you have a nice stay like my base that we're going to
need to paint but before we go that the glue I haven't left it for very long so
it is still malleable but so you can push it make sure that it is going to
lie flat so I just make sure that it is actually the right sort of shape now I'm
just gonna base it with black acrylic I didn't have any spray paint left so I
just used black acrylic paint you can spray paint it and then and then paint
it with acrylic but it's painted it black for this demonstration and I
didn't let it dry I just went straight into the next color which is brown and
then I'd start to add yellow as well so really just making a mucky sort of Missy
kind of brownie black yellow greenies color so if you'd expect a dank dripping
cave this is the sort of color scheme I envision being envisaged
invisible its you later not envisage it being so just applying more and more
yellow and remember when these things dry they tend to dry darker and finally
I'm just going to apply white so the fresher fresher drips and things are
going to be the white so usually on the peaks and just down the sides is where
you apply most of the white where the water will flow off and that's the
calcification of the water landing on the top of the static light and if
you've never gone into caves you know what I'm talking about so then we have
it just let it dry and then it here it is on a tile so you can see just placing
it on a tile and it fits in quite nicely so there was a rip-roaring adventure in
